question: 学ぶ
userExplanation: 学ぶ sounds a little more serious compared to 習う
sourceMnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>study</kanji> or <kanji>learning</kanji>. When you do these things, what ends up happening? You learn. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to learn</vocabulary>. 

There is another word that means "to learn" that is going to be more common, which is <ja>習う</ja>. You'll learn this one later on. <ja>学ぶ</ja> sounds a little more serious compared to <ja>習う</ja>, so keep that in mind when you use it.
sourceReadingMnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the <ja>まな</ja> part to learn this word's reading. Think about a class you're taking. It's a manners class, and you're there <vocabulary>to learn</vocabulary> <reading>manner</reading>s (<ja>まな</ja>). Imagine this study of manners and imagine yourself practicing it.
